JOCdPyxGqedAp3_cxISBIQ.text: Solid sandwiches. The matzo ball soup is fantastic! I've had the salmon sandwich on pits and the eggplant on pita- both very good. Byo - no corkerage fee!

NW5buHRTHAhXnaJyULOOdQ.text: Had the Knishwich & Matzo Ball soup. Thoroughly enjoyed them both! This place is definitely on my Pittsburgh brunch list.

wlTRzOvUsXbQLcdTnkQBhg.text: Great service! No wait, actually owned by Pamela's! The food was great-- maybe even better than next door! All sorts of Yiddish references and fun Jewish foods that are hard to find elsewhere. Love the challah French toast. Highly recommended!!

uBz2h-w0Z5zgjwLaSkpjpA.text: I was there for lunch today.  The new buffet table was wonderful.  I had Chopped Liver that was soooo good, it reminded me of my mother's chopped liver (may she rest in peace)!  There has been plenty of chopped liver that has passed through these lips and none nearly as good and tasty as what I had today.   Also, there were so many other delicious items on the table, I barely made room for dessert.  The chocolate bubka was delicious.  By this point I was busting at the seams and couldn't finish everything on my plate.  I didn't want to leave.  Also, the price for the amount and quality of food was quite reasonable.  I will be returning, but my poor wasteline may never be the same ;)

c1yJXSzbeHGMIJZlkZHlDw.text: I won't worry about "authenticity" here, because most of the things on the menu were things I had never heard of or eaten before. However, the waiter very nicely explained kreplach and kishka to us, as well as explaining the process behind the Montreal smoked meat. The main thing is that everything was absolutely delicious and reasonably priced.  We ended up ordering 3 things: the poutine, the Kreplach, and the 1/2 pound smoked meat sandwich on wheat. We are poutine aficionados, ok? And this poutine can easily stand next that of Point Brugges/Park Bruge. It was amazing.   The kreplach was great too, but obviously the real star was the sandwich. Really delicious and flavorful. In fact, there was so much food with just 3 dishes for the two of us that we couldn't finish the sandwich and had to take half of it home (while my wife made short work of the poutine). To top it off, it's a BYO, so our dinner was enjoyed with some beers from It's Doggin' It down the street. Total came to $32 with tip included for all of this. This is a much more reasonable price range than what Aji Picante was charging in this same space.  This is probably my favorite restaurant in Squirrel Hill now. We need to support this place and make sure places with interesting and delicious food stay in the neighborhood.

S1etqhxWA3E4xSQcg47f6Q.text: The meat is hella authentic, Jewish spices. Great options. Super relaxed laid back environment. Fast service. And hostess/server milissa is an amazing human being. Such a sweet, kind, friendly person!!! We had a great experience.

kQM98oC7obgYyoc8YQBxGA.text: Just finished eating for the first time at this restaurant.  Enjoyed the food immensely.  I have not eaten such delectable kreplach in decades!  Chewy dumplings with a delicious brisket filling!   The corn beef was authentic smoked meat.  Highly recommend the Russian rye bread.  This is high praise from one New Yorker who has has had her share of corn beef on rye.  Sad that I had to go all the way to Pittsburgh to find such a good deli.

txEHrBbKryHUY8WGgObhSA.text: I would add that the restaurant does not offer the traditional delicatessen fare of potato and macaroni salad, another flaw.  The response from Pam C., below, demonstrates that she is an honorable and gracious business owner.  Indeed, the restaurant is not for me, but I will remember her generosity.

PEBnCKVVEesP_auubpmiGA.text: I went here twice. The first time I had an egg lox muffin which I would have given 5 stars since it hit the spot. The next time I had scrambled egg with lox and I think it had cream cheese on it which I did not like very much. This however isn't a knock on them since I am merely not a cream cheese fan and did not account for it being included. The service was very friendly as my waitress engaged me in pleasant conversation. While my last meal was still tasty it did kind of sit in my stomach for sometime after. Again though I don't really fault the establishment as smoked salmon can have that effect on me. This place gets a strong 4-star rating from me. I can see myself enjoying this kind of meal more in colder weather perhaps.

HNV9_SEhR091OhlFmSJJmQ.text: Been looking forward to this place opening since they put up the awning 2 weeks ago. Had a tasty, tender brisket sandwich! Cured and smoked on premises. My wife had the T.O.M., a brisket with gravy on a challah with a wonderful Kishke!  Topped it off with their Grilled Babka with Salted Caramel Ice Cream. Lovely! We will definitely be back! (Suggestion: I would love them to serve some fires and knishes!)

UbLOFqxagWltRXta9RgCDg.text: A very pleasant surprise in terms of quality!! We went for dinner but would recommend it more for lunch based on the type of food they serve. But it was all delicious!

SEEF3kc-_aBY9K5EBhXQnw.text: Solidly good, especially the brunch menu. Do yourself a favor and order the babka. I don't know why people wait in line for sadness Pamela's when Nu is right next door.

gN2CU3yE7F8FSLNOiqW1RQ.text: I was excited when I saw there was a new place that actually serves Jewish food in sq hill. I was really disappointed when I found out that most of the food isn't actually kosher. I don't really understand how you can call yourself a Jewish bistro if Jewish people cant actually eat most of what's on the menu.

DcqaKS2fvB-hswrYEK4EKg.text: I came with a friend who referred this to me because it just opened a few weeks ago. It's a Jewish Restaraunt and it was my very first time eating Jewish food. The interior was very open and clean- the walls were decorated with pictures and descriptions of the Jewish food they served there which was very helpful for someone like me. In the back right corner was the open kitchen where we could see the chef prepare our food. Our waitress was very friendly and forth coming as to giving us advice.  We first ordered an appetizer of Latke Tots- "shredded potato, onion, and schmaltz fried crispy tot style served with apple ketchup and sour cream" We LOVED it. My friend got the special which was a brisket with cheddar and apples (if I remember correctly) and I ordered the salmon burger- "fresh salmon patty, nova lox, capers Israeli salad under the burger party with dill sauce on a bulkie roll " Both were absolutely delicious. The burger was perfectly cooked and the only fishy taste was the smoked salmon slice on top. The texture, flavor and everything else was a delicate flavor and nothing was overpowering.  We shared the desert of the salted caramel ice cream on a chocolate brioche bread and oh goodness that was heavenly. They make their own ice cream which is my favorite part - but with a thick slice of warmed chocolate bread, a single scoop of their salted caramel ice cream was placed on top.  Because Nu had their open kitchen, my friend and I were able to compliment the chef. I find it very personal and assured to see and know who is making my food and the chef himself was a very friendly man.  I loved this place so much I went back a week later to order what my friend had only to find out they weren't making it anymore! Hopefully they put it back on the menu someday!

0SWiDeFRHDoipJl41kq7iA.text: Love this place. Great coffee, great service, really cool specials (bring back the smoked meat eggrolls!!!). A really honestly fresh take on Jewish cuisine, and the smoked meat is just amazing. I'm here usually once a week.

vGFXnz1mNUMfFJzWxqvP7Q.text: Great stuff! The food is delicious and the staff is very nice and helpful. We sat near the kitchen and chatted with the chef a bit during dinner.  We started with the blintzes, which were tasty and well seasoned. My wife got the Nu BLT, and it was awesome. Seriously, you have to try it, the chicken skin bacon is great. I got the special deli burger with a fried egg on it. The burger was juicy and well cooked, the smoked meat was tender, and the fried egg was perfectly runny. I intend to try the matzo balls and soup next time. Give it a try, you'll like it.

photos.caption: Photo of NU Jewish Bistro - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Special, Dec 6, 2013: deli burger. Burger with smoked meat, lettuce, tomato and onion on a onion roll. Added an extra fried egg.

iYuSkt2vH-k3MAqQYsCUkg.text: WOW their matzoh ball soup is amazing.  That deep brown, flavorful broth is to die for.  Portions are great for your money too.  I'll be back!  :)

LRm3IhA6Jpt2mIPnoKVwvw.text: yum yum yum great hot dog. this is a great addition to the Jewish community of SQ. HILL!!!!

tYqxxTOlmcNAf_YFbmXddQ.text: Nu has an attitude towards food that I can only describe as "cheeky."  They take classic foods and tweak them just enough to expand your imagination, but not so much that they become unrecognizable concoctions.  They hang framed wikipedia descriptions of their menu items on their walls: a tacit acknowledgement that smartphone-wielding diners have no excuse for not trying something just because they don't immediately recognize its name.  They serve coleslaw sides in chinese takeout boxes, which is patently hilarious.  I wish more restaurants had this playful attitude towards food without diluting its essential quality.  Too often "culinary humor" means offering insulin-coma-inducing menu items only palatable to people who lost a bet, the profoundly stoned, and Adam Richmond.  Part of the genius of Nu is its ability to tickle your funny bone, your palate, and your dietary sensibilities all at once.  Disclaimer: I'm as Gentile as they come, so I really had no context coming in for what constituted traditional Jewish comfort food.  I visited Nu with a friend of mine of Russian Jewish ancestry to help me figure out the menu.  I went with the fairly safe choice of a Reuben Knishwich since it was based on a sandwich that I knew I liked, while my friend ordered the stuffed cabbage Knishwich since she was awed that someone had managed to combine two of her favorite childhood foods.  Both of us left stuffed and happy.  Nu is clearly good for both newcomers in search of a good introduction and oldtimers ready for a fresh take on the classics.  I hope to be back soon.

f4_-JKWuJX4-FBwfwezWMA.text: I thought this deli was below average. Maybe my bar was set too high. I thought the meat was a little dry and the chicken noodle soup was bland. The portions are small for a deli. I did not leave full. It is also pricey for what you get. It is cash only. Lunch for 4 is $100 so bring cash. Service was fair but seemed a little disorganized.  -Hungry in Sq Hill and wishing for a REAL Deli

Z61UfAPefOjbToro2ym2_Q.text: We entered here on a weekday some weeks back and were the only customers.   So what is a Jewish bistro?  I didn't know either.  However, it is a strong four start restaurant.  We got the sampler appetizer and while one item was not to my taste it was not poorly prepared.  Everything else was excellent.   We both also got sandwiches we selected with the help of our waitress. They were both really good.  I got corned beef and it was just great.  I was not disappointed.  Do try it yourself.  Some interesting menu choices.

oGOvQxEP0YalfMlT82CELA.text: Aji Picante was my favorite restaurant in Squirrel Hill, and I was sad to see it disappear a few months back. Fortunately, it appeared to have a promising successor in Nu, which has the same ownership (Pamela's) and a menu that is inventive and appropriate for the neighborhood.  I visited Nu with some friends last week and was thoroughly impressed. We started with the appetizer platter ($15), a bountiful array of meat blintzes, kreplach, fried potato puffs, and fried pickles. All were quite tasty, especially the fried items.  Moving on to the main courses, it is difficult to choose from all the tantalizing sandwiches, each one featuring Nu's house-smoked meats. We ultimately went with the Reuben Knishwich and the Upstreet Dip ($12 each). The former is a creative take on my favorite sandwich: the meat, cheese and kraut are finely diced and baked into a pastry. The result is a delicious and filling stomach bomb that is surprisingly different from a traditional Reuben. The dip was a more standard affair consisting of a baguette filled with thick slabs of juicy brisket slathered in cheese and horseradish sauce.  It too was excellent and generously portioned.  Nu is BYOB, so we brought some wine and beer to drink with our meal; when the check arrived, we were pleased to see no corkage fee. All told the bill came to $20/person after tax and tip, a fantastic bargain for such a delicious and filling meal. Service was friendly and attentive.   In closing, Nu is a welcome addition to Pittsburgh; I don't know of any other place in the city that serves this type of food. Their menu manages to be both traditional and creative, and their execution is spot-on. Here's hoping it sticks around.

2CSddj8PpHmRTbXaK8wjmQ.text: I love good deli food.  I've purposefully searched down the best from Brooklyn, to Boston, to Boca and I haven't found a corned beef on rye that didn't agree with me.    Nu brings a fresh twist to old classics.  Not only do they do traditional deli well, they elevate the art form with a spark of creativity and fun I've never seen brought to deli fare.  Any deli will serve you matzo balls and latkes, but only Nu will give you mini lake tots and "Jewish Penicillin" brisket stuffed matzo ball soup.  My friends got the reuben knishwich (A reuben on a croissant pastry bun), and the Neufalleta, a tangy chunky olive Tapenade muffulettas with classic deli turkey, meat, and Gouda, and a Challah Cristo, a juicy turkey monte cristo with swiss on french toast challah bread. We finished by sharing a killer chocolate desert bread topped off with gourmet salted caramel ice cream and cinnamon puff pastries donuts that had warm custard on the inside.    It's also BYOB, so you can wash down your meal with friends on the cheap.  The staff was also very friendly, and helpful with any questions and terminology.  I'd give them 6 stars if I could!  Eating here felt like I had Matisyahu perform at my Bar Mitzvah, a fresh take on Jewish culture, with both respectful nods to the past, and a spark of revolution, with fresh, funky updates for the future.

6F8G4XKJcHjdl6W-7D8WRA.text: This will probably be a 5 after I try a couple more items. Out of the 3 things I've ordered here, two have definitely been 5s. My first time here I went for my beloved matzoh ball soup. I'm a harsh matzoh ball critic and this didn't meet my expectations. To be fair, no restaurant matzoh ball soup ever has. It just doesn't have the same flavor as the matzoh ball I have at family dinners. The broth in Nu's version was delicious; however the matzoh ball was underwhelming as far as flavor and I prefer a softer texture.   Nevertheless, on another dreary day I wanted soup, and I came in deciding to instead try the kreplach and enticed by the specials board offering of noodle kugel (possible one of my all time favorite foods if done well). Wow am I glad I did. The brisket kreplach combined with the chicken soup to create an almost gravy like flavor. So savory. And the cup was loaded with a gigantic dumpling, lots of chicken, and carrots (carrots are key to good chicken soup in my opinion). But the True shining star was the noodle kugel. Dear god...if I could eat 10 orders of it without having to be rolled out of here in pain, it would be very tempting. This was better than family dinner kugel and I didn't think that was possible. So unbelievably rich and yummy. Don't kid yourself...this is basically a dessert not a normal side. But it's a damn good one.

4KYIiCHdg9aMvsHC-OF9BA.text: I just visited Nu for the first time today for lunch, and It blew my mind.  I've been to my share of delis, here and in New York City, and have always been a bit underwhelmed by the traditional comfort food served.  I respect that the food here is firmly rooted in the classics, ie. matso ball soup, roast turkey, brisket, latkes.  What I loved was that it wasn't stuck on repeat with them.    Let's get to what I got: I had the latke tots, awesome little deep-fried latkes that were served with this savory apple sauce that I wanted to take home.  I also had the reuben knishwich, which was heavenly.  All of the classic reuben ingredients, encased in a flaky pastry dough that was unbelievably tender and easier to eat neatly than the sandwich version.  My stomach is happily full of warm corned beef and swiss cheesy goodness; I didn't even feel the cold of this sub-freezing December day.  I hope this place is accepted and supported by my neighbors.  It may not be Kosher enough for some of them, but there are a lot of us here in Squirrel Hill that just wish we had a Jewish grandmother, and this place has the Jewish penicillin for you.

8VeDAlxmLly2UpRRe0PWVw.text: I drove by a few days ago, and noticed that the signage where Aji Picante used to be had changed... intriguing! So, when we didn't have any food at home and needed a place to go, I suggested that we see if Nu had opened.  Nu bills itself as a modern Jewish bistro (the name is Yiddish). Inside, it looks only a little like Aji Picante used to, mainly because they have added an open kitchen in the middle. I prefer this incarnation, and think Nu has a lot of potential. The food is distinctively Jewish, with an emphasis on sandwiches, soups, and deli salads (think smoked fish or eggs). The aesthetic is similar to Porch and its ilk, down to the chalkboard announcements of the day's offerings. So, consider it an upscale Jewish deli, but with much nicer service! You seat yourself when you walk in, and the menus are kept on the table, just like they are at Pamela's. Service was very sweet.  We had 1) Jewish Penicillin (i.e. chicken soup), 2) chili, 3) the special brisket sandwich, and 4) mama's meat blintzes. The chicken soup was quite good, and definitely worth having if you are in need of some comfort food when you come down with the inevitable cold/flu. I had it with a matzo ball, which was a bit on the dense side. The chili was overly salty, and almost completely beef, with minimal beans. Some people may prefer that version of chili; I do not. I prefer a balance of beans to meat to tomato, and this was just too meaty for me, even though I am quite carnivorous! The brisket was also a little on the dry side. The blintzes were pretty tasty, but could have used a bit more filling (or maybe we are just spoiled by grandma's blintzes... unclear).  I know this review makes this place sound not so good. Let me be clear - I think Nu has a lot of potential, and we fully intend on coming back again once they have gotten a little more time under their belt. Despite feeling a bit "meh" on the food this first time, we liked it enough that we really want to see it succeed.  If you're vegetarian, you can pretty much write this place off. There is a salad or two that might work for you, but otherwise, this is not your place.

vJUTkjxaOUPqmb-JmwzO3Q.text: Been here before and will come again. Great service and great food. Latkes are awesome!

UvllBmwQz3uR7JFqH0MmXQ.text: The food is tasty and fairly-priced, especially when you consider all that you get with a meal and the size of the stacked sandwiches. I had the Jewbano (their take on a Cubano) and it was tangy and delicious. The homemade pickles were a nice touch and I enjoyed the Matzo Ball Soup.  The service was great: friendly and efficient without hovering.   Added bonus: While Nu doesn't serve alcohol, you can bring beer or wine without being charged a corking fee. Our server even brought us wine glasses.

stAZRvozyZzFt29BP4pHLA.text: A strong 3 stars. Nu provides a decent, but far from overwhelming experience - in fact a slightly disappointing experience, and we got out of it with a "meh" on the lips. It is good, no, better than most restaurants on Murray, but it is not as good as it should.  The restaurant itself looks fine (it shares its door with Pamela): there is enough space between tables, simple furniture, open kitchen, decent light.  The food was not overwhelming. The blintzes with meat (appetizer) were the best dish of the lunch. We  particularly enjoyed the horseradish remoulade that went with it (the highlight of the lunch imo).   The jewish penicillin with the matzo ball and pasta was quite bland, and I have had many better chicken broths. The brisket sandwich was quite tasty, although not light.   Prices are fine. A complaint: they clean tables with a smelly product. Surely they know that taste and smell influence each other, and smelling cleaning product is quite unpleasant when the nearby table is being cleaned.

hv_yYSF1f3KwDm7ZvTmv6g.text: I probably eat at Nu at least once a week. The service is excellent and the food is always wonderful. The chocolate egg cream is so good! The main dishes are good, and they take it to the next level with attention to the little things.  If you want toast with your brunch eggs, you can get outstanding rye bread with real butter. A side of coleslaw is obviously made fresh there, and is scrumptious.  My favorite meal is the Sabich, a warm pita wrapped around fried eggplant, cabbage, a fried egg and some kind of glorious sauce -- so good!  My husband is a meat eater, and loves everything he gets there.

v_1UXDYJ6_KSz6asGOSLhg.text: The food was incredible. We had the Benny with smoked meat and the shakshuka. Both were really flavorful and prepared flawlessly. Don't wait in line over at Pamela's and get fast friendly service at NU.

photos.caption: Photo of NU Jewish Bistro - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Benny with smoked meat and crispy latkes!
Photo of NU Jewish Bistro - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Shakshuka!

BHaw-F_L33CHfogyRdT-kw.text: Went here on a Sunday at around 5pm. A couple of outdoor tables had customers, but not a soul inside. The waitress was very prompt and nicely explained the menu, a beverage special for the day, and the day's menu and soup specials. I ordered a cup of Jewish penicillin with a matzo ball and a half smoked meat sandwich. The waitress explained Montreal smoked meat and that they do theirs in house.   My companion ordered potato latkes and kishka, which she had never had, and I haven't since I was a kid.   My soup came out first, as requested. A very generous crock! The broth was nicely flavored wit bits of chicken and carrots, and the good sized ball a perfect consistency by my standards (I don't like them TOO airy). Served with a side of wonton-type strips, but tastily fried in schmaltz for a change.   After I inhaled that, my half sandwich arrived (more like a whole) with a newer half dill and a takeout carton of a good not-too-creamy coleslaw. I remember Montreal smoked meat having WAY more flavor and way less fat strips, but this wasn't awful.   My companion's latkes came with a small side of sour cream (where's the apple sauce?).  The 3-4 CD-sized disks looked delicious, and had a good consistency, but had a very odd, unappealing flavor. Her 3-4 kishka slices had a dose of gravy, and were decent, but my memory remembers stuffed derma (kishka) being more much savory and salty, less sweet.   So all in all, I'd order the soup in a heart (attack) beat for comfort, and might try a different sandwich, but the food didn't make me vaklempt.

XtPvgeFBebgMRAc6-Bkvww.text: Soups, meats, sides--all spectacular. Been here three times and nothing disappoints. BYOB. Return visit for brunch--my wife said the French toast was the best she ever had. Hash superb also.

ohon-Fkp0ud32CM1KE01kA.text: Ate there with friends who have lived in New York and know from corned beef. It was the best they'd ever had. Jewish penicillin was good for what ailed us. One warning: don't believe the server if she describes a portion as small.

cHJ0IKmqY335D-tOLeS3OQ.text: Came in here and tried the Jewish Penicillin, or their chicken noodle soup with two large matzah balls. It was my first time tasting matzah and it was alright. I guess I'm not a fan of matzah itself (apparently, their matzah is the best in Pittsburgh). I just found it flavorless, heavy, and slightly nauseating (it doesn't look very pretty). The soup was good though - wonderfully flavored chicken broth with carrots. Interior has this diner-esque feel to it.

kt6L8-ZTfdE_Cm0xftecOw.text: Where do I start? The broth alone in the Jewish penicillin is amazing. I got the T.O.M and my boyfriend got the Jewish dip. So good. BYOB doesn't hurt either. Didn't have enough room for dessert but will definitely be back for the Babka.

photos.caption: Photo of NU Jewish Bistro - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. T.O.M with a side of macaroni salad and pickle. So good.

DYrXfY1kxVnlshwvBfvWOw.text: The hands-down best Jewish deli foods in Pittsburgh. Really friendly service. Get a Montreal Smoked Meat sandwich with a pickle and some macaroni salad.

vX5ZhVZVOOefo5ea6ExT_Q.text: I visited Nu Deli in June of 2014. I had been meaning to visit ever since I saw "Montreal Smoked Meat" on the menu- possibly one of the greatest deli options out there. The decor was nice, everything was clean and we were promptly seated. The waitress was quick to serve us water and take our order (though to be fair, there were very few people there at a 5pm that Sunday). The first thing I noticed was that they had already raised their prices compared to the menu I saw posted online. (I do find it a hassle that they have no website with menu posting). But I was willing to live with the increase, as I've never seen a place offer Montreal Smoked Meat outside of Montreal.   I ordered that 1/2 lb sandwich, with coleslaw. At first inspection, its about a 4 inch tall sandwich with plenty of meat. But i like to eat my sandwiches open-face, so I opened it up, and suddenly I'm staring at strips of fat. I would say probably a third of the sandwich was pure fat. Half of it was decent corned beef, and the rest was corned beef laced together with fat. I was somewhat disappointed how much effort I had to put into dissecting my sandwich to remove the fat. The corned beef itself was tasty, though not as Montreal-style as I remember. In fairness, since I don't have a picture of the tasty-looking "before" picture, I won't post the mound of fat "after picture". I was a bit surprised the waitress ignored it when she took away my plate.  The coleslaw was cream-based, which I generally don't prefer to vinegar based. But it was tasty. It was in a little chinese take-out container, so as I got closer to the bottom, it was really just a soup of coleslaw cream, which I can't really eat.  My fiance ordered the "Grilled Salmich"- basically a salmon fillet atop a pita. She says it was fine. I tasted it too, and I thought it was good, but not particularly flavorful.  Overall, I wouldn't call this a replacement for really good Jewish Deli based on these two dishes. In NYC, you get tons more, leaner corned beef, at a price that is only a few dollars higher than this. I didn't dislike it, but it just didn't astound me enough to be put in the rotation of regular frequented restaurants.

photos.caption: Photo of NU Jewish Bistro - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Top of the NU Menu, July 2014
Photo of NU Jewish Bistro - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Bottom of the NU Menu, July 2014

eDJ_qQ22HUrGcOCtMyGaJQ.text: not worth the !$$  a pickle cost extra but the stale bread is complimentary! They defiantly don't sell enough sandwiches to put a Great product forward......if you like dry corn beef than give this a try!

7fvkxkb-QzsLtc3q1bgCBA.text: Every time we go to Nu, we are treated incredibly, the food is fantastic. i am so glad we live down the street

JJBmp2nwNA85aweszfrH6g.text: This is a hidden gem. Located next to a very popular restaurant by the same owners. I would highly recommend going to Nu instead. The food was amazing! Beyond your normal breakfast fare. We are not from the area but can't wait to come back on our next trip.

Xy954rLQ-xq6ykYbtoHKQA.text: Wow this was great! The staff was friendly, and the food was fabulous! I ordered the lox omelet, which was cooked to perfection. The nosh table was awesome, especially the African chicken peanut stew. The sweets on the table were quite strongly flavored, but were sized appropriately for how strong they were.

rn71xcfAyMl3o8TPmFKlRw.text: My boyfriend and I have ate there twice now. We started off with the potato latkes which were delicious and curbed my severe hunger. Then I had the french dip which was very good, it has a sauce which I believe is horseradish based that I really enjoyed. The beau had the jewbano which has the most scrumptious smoked meat I have ever tried!! However, they do not have any desserts right now that cater to lactose free individuals which is why I cannot give them a full 5 stars.

2reUSCEo32AFZhYrYP4qAw.text: Excellent establishment adjacent to a simple dinner owned by the same owners.. my folks and I truly enjoyed the ambiance and classic dish. I ordered a rubin it was tasteful but a bit overbearing saturated in oil. I'll be back again when I come visit Pittsburgh.

7EFko-33kMjbmEDwx3emow.text: Comfort food prepared with authentic recipes.  Our waitress was familiar from when she worked at Aji Picante.  Everyone was helpful and friendly.  Their most popular dish is the Upstreet Dip, a brisket sandwich with caramelized onions.  We ordered that and it  was very good. We also ordered the Nu Nu Platter and the Matzo Ball Soup.  Everything was very filling.

Photo of NU Jewish Bistro - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. potato latkes and kreplach

Z-3cqWMhqmdNNiy-dQusrQ.text: Ok, I have now been here a few times and I think that I would still consider it A-OK. It is not a place that I am rushing out to eat at but it is not a place that I am actively avoiding. If I am in Squirrel Hill (and I am there at least 2 days a week), I am hungry (which is always), and I want something quick, I will always pick NU. They are A-OK.   The prices are are little high. $12.00 for a sandwich, even if it comes with a side is a little too much for me. But I will say they taste amazing.   The Sabich: Crispy fried eggplant, Israeli salad,fried egg, tahini & amba sauce, served in fresh pita. I have had this twice. I really love this sandwich. The fried eggplant were a big draw for me to order this sandwich. I love eggplant and these are crispy and fried to perfection. I asked for extra sauce since I like my sandwiches on the sloppier side. I do not know how they originally come but asking for the extra sauce made the sandwich perfect!  JEWBANO: Smoked meat, roasted brisket, pickles, swiss cheese & mustard, pressed on a bulkie. TO DIE FOR. This is the one order that I just was hungry and said, "eh" to the price and went for it. This sandwich was so big that I could only eat half. HALF!!! I probably could have eaten all of it but didn't want to look like a porker and wanted my fiance to try a bit of it. The smoked meat was so flavorful and juicy. There was not a dry part to any of the bites that I tried. Roasted brisket!!! BRISKET!! This is one of my favorite meats. I really love it. How can you not enjoy a sandwich with brisket in it! I am not a fan of the pickles. I do not know why! I love pickles but these ones are just not for me. I eat them....sometimes but I do not grab for them. And if you know me, I am a pickled vegetable grabber (I don't know how that makes me look...). This sandwich is a must if you come here. So good.   I always take my food to go. During the less than 5 minute walk to my second job the food stays perfect. It does not get mushy, it does not get that weird "cooking in the wrapper" taste to it. It stays just as it should.   I have yet to try any desserts. Or the noshes. I would like to experience NU as a sit down with friends dinner or lunch. I think that it would really expand my idea and view of the place.   I would suggest, if you are thinking about it, to at least try it out.

6Eg_pHSHVCOuduSF1umUPA.text: I am sorry to have to write this, for I wanted a place to have a good meal (sandwich) like I have gotten at the Carnegie Deli in New York - this was so far from that - the corned beef sandwich - I wanted something simple and hard to mess up - it was not only messed up it was not what any new York Jew would have recognized as a corned beef sandwich. It was dried up sandpaper like meat. This is what a corned beef sandwich should look like - dzakinsdeli.com/gfx/pics... - I am glad I only got the half a sandwich with the soup - I brought most of the half even home so my wife could try (I did not want to say anything till I had someone I trust taste this drek too) she spit it out in disgust. Matzoh-ball soup was like my mother's - the problem is my mother cannot cook either - when we visit her she makes me cook - The Matzoh-balls were a nice size but hard and seemingly undercooked and without flavor. The soup itself was not that bad and had the crap at the bottom you would expect with homemade soup. Overall if someone reads this with any power to do so "Bring a good Jewish deli to Pittsburgh PLEASE!!" I gave the stars for the egg cream -

aIt_gJguLFoNGOmcSUy5Pw.text: NU bills itself as a modern take on Jewish cuisine, or something to that effect.  "Modern" innovations seem to include a Reuben Knishwich, and enormous knish containing Reuben filling, and a couple other things like that. I didn't get the knishwich, but I do like a good knish, and the people we went with swore this was a worthy innovation.   I got the Rachel with a "Montreal-style" smoked meat. It's not a huge sandwich in the style of say, the Carnegie Deli, but while not overwhelming (in a good way), the meat was delicious and then sandwich was still ample.  I also got an order of kishka; I'd been struggling to explain it earlier in the week to my partner, and found it to be a good example of the form.  I'm used to it in derma, like at Katz's Deli and Corned Beef Emporium in Toronto, but I don't suppose there's a significant difference in the taste. The gravy was also good, though I would have liked more of it; I got fries (also good), specifically to mop the gravy up with, and there wasn't nearly enough.  Perhaps I should have ordered the poutine if that's how I feel, but still.  For dessert the couple we were with split the matzah brittle ice cream sunday.  The matzah's coated with chocolate, nuts, and some sea salt.  I had a bite, and it was pretty good, but given that passover had just ended, I wanted something a little more *leavened*, so my partner and I split the "babka sundae".  Usually she has a couple bites of dessert, and then I finish it off, but this marks a rare dessert where it was so good we actually ordered a second portion.  You get a thick slice of warmed-up, gooey chocolate and cinnamon-y babka, with a scoop of french vanilla on top, caramel drizzle, and sea salt.  It's not especially ground breaking, but it is darned good.  They had good mustard on the table, the service was exceptional, and we enjoyed our BYOB wine.  We also each had a quarter of a new dill pickle which was good.  Again, I guess I'm of the school of deli-excess: I want a sandwich I can barely pick up, loads of gravy on my kishka, and ideally, and a full pickle, along with perhaps a selection of different pickles (I feel like we're in a bit of a pickle revolution; tons of places make their own pickles and pickled vegetables, so that would have been a cool plus). But these are minor peccadilloes; it may not match a traditional deli in Toronto or NYC, but I'd happily come back here if we were going to stick around Pittsburgh.

LBTZV4pB31lT5jiwD_76Rg.text: Normally when I write a review, I mention a particular meal and try to give readers some idea of what menu items I recommend (or don't recommend).   Well, the thing about Nu is that my husband and I go there fairly often, and we've tried most of the menu, and we recommend it all. OK, I'll try to be more specific: Any version of the chicken soup (flavorful stock, great matzo balls), anything with the Montreal smoked meat, the sausage bean soup, the coleslaw, the pickles, Portions are huge, by the way. Nu's cup is everyone else's bowl!  We only recently discovered Nu's brunch menu, and it has actually lured us away from Pamela's next door. (Of course, Pamela's and Nu are under the same ownership, so they're still getting pretty much all of our our brunch business.) The Jewish biscuits and gravy may be the epitome of World Cuisine.  Last, but far from least, the staff is friendly and the service is great.

056DVmwRFzE3lN5lPpxxAw.text: Terrible food the one time I ate there, but decided for some stupid reason to try it again.  I didn't even get a chance, though, because both the hostess and the manager decided to give me grief about my service dog.    To heck with them; I just left and went elsewhere, where I *know* the food is good and they welcome both my dog and me - Silks across the street.    I'm fed up with having to still educate businesses about the law who should know better by now.  Which most other businesses around here obviously do know at this point.  No one should have to run this kind of obnoxious course just to get a bite to eat.    They were at least pretty polite, but you know, it doesn't make a paying customer feel the least bit welcome when we have to meet people literally physically blocking the path into the business, confronting us, demanding documentation and have to educate them about why we have to be allowed the same rights to eat there as anyone else - and specifically why no documentation or special garb is required, and why it's illegal to ask for it or require it.    But after the hostess took off to find the manager because she didn't know the law, suddenly she became an expert and started trying to tell me what was required and what was not.

r30as6IT1hz2sGz0KdfdwA.text: I've been to Nu three times in six month.  The first time I came for the Jewish Penicillin (matzo ball soup).  I'd had a terrible day, was sick and needed some love.  It hit the spot.  The last two times we've come as a family for brunch.  We've covered most of the items on the menu.  While not as diverse of a menu as Square in Regent Square, I feel the brunch is quite possible the best we have in Pittsburgh.  You really can't go wrong.  The flavors are amazing.

HQtqWXYFYS_87TCvz4ddkQ.text: I visited Nu this past weekend and loved the new menu and buffet  aka nosh table. We had a group of 4. Everyone got something different. I loved my Nu Benny ( eggs Benedict) best but enjoyed everyone's. It was really fun eating at the nosh table with friends and comparing things. Reminds me a bit of lydias concept but this was homey and welcoming.   The atmosphere is bright and cheery. You can linger and chat and the staff treats you like family. It's definitely a new concept for Pittsburgh. More New Yorkish I think. Whatever I'm sure some will miss the old style dining but this is delightful  and fun. As Nu advertises kinda like sitting at your moms brunch table on a Sunday as she just keeps bringing out more food.   Loved the house made lox and the chopped liver is the best I've ever had. Love that it's unlimited at the nosh table. And that it constantly changes. If you're looking for grand dining in a formal atmosphere better head to grand concourse and lydias as they are great. If you're looking for great food and a bright positive atmosphere this is your place.

yN0mAZ23vFmgW0jgdUZd2Q.text: Stopped in for an early lunch.   I was the only customer at the time.  The Pastrami was excellent.   The bread could have been better.  I would prefer if a place like this would stop with the small bread over stuffed sandwich. I really just want a nicer larger slice of bread for my sandwich, you don't have to make it hard to fit in my mouth.  But seriously - the Pastrami was made there they said, and it seemed to be so - wonderful!  I give it 3 stars- Most of you would give it more, but I think 3 stars is good.

3_PkNZAy5scGQzMo_2b4CA.text: Apparently this place has been open since November, but I had no idea because of a lack of signage.  Luckily, management decided to finally invest in a bright blue awning that caught my attention while driving down Murray Ave.  I said to my PIC, "We should try that place."  Then, lo and behold a few days later, we were there, enjoying quite a pleasurable Jew-ish bistro lunch.  The sign worked!  Now, this place isn't Kosher or anything (hence "Jew-ish"), but my PIC who is of the Chosen People has stated that this is probably one of the best places to get Jewish inspired food in Pittsburgh, and that's saying something from him.  Me, being a Shiksa and unfamiliar with this type of cuisine can't say the same.  However, I *AM* a lover of food, I can say with certaninty that it was pretty darn good.  I got the T.O.M. and even though I'm not eating bread at the moment, the brisket and kishka (think meatloaf shaped sausage thing) were excellent and drenched with this tasty, tasty gravy.  The PIC got the Jewbano, which he devoured.  I even broke my "no bread" rule to take a bite of his awesome looking sandwich.  Luckily I didn't lose a finger in the process!    Additionally, the wait staff seemed very friendly and were attentive to us.  The only thing I didn't really like was the awkwardness of having to go through the kitchen to get to the shared bathroom with Pamela's next door.

IteZKa-5uXSydgruftBQoQ.text: Omg you need to come here! Melt in your mouth food, corned beef and brisket ridiculous and  this food rocks!

photos.caption: Photo of NU Jewish Bistro - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Omg the sampler platter is sooo good!

UXwOrwWnr9OJN0KAnw7Ymg.text: Great food, relaxed atmosphere, and outstanding staff!  I visited them on a recent trip to Pittsburgh and was exhausted enough to leave my wallet at the checkout counter. Milissa went above and beyond to track me down. That type of hospitality is amazing and really helped keep my trip on track. I was traveling with my 14 month old son and the last thing I needed was a lost wallet. This crew made me feel comforted and welcome not just with the food but also their hospitality. Kudos.

azmp4TtpBQEGS6_qs-OPKQ.text: We came here looking for a place that was still serving food and didn't have a wait in the evening. We came in and there was no one else in the restaurant at all. We were seated quickly and ordered, but the server couldn't answer any of the questions we had about the food. Surprising for a place you would think would receive a fair amount of questions about their food.  It came out reasonably fast for having no other customers. It was bland. I had a salad and the fish was okay, but the portion was small. The rest of the salad was lettuce. And had no flavor at all.  I would list the rest of the orders, but they all shared the same thing in common. They were all bland.

vcOM__Gv6oGdBsHdYbsysw.text: Great modern, hip take to classic Jewelry deli! Go here! And service was excellent!!!

photos.caption: Photo of NU Jewish Bistro - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Potato pancakes!!!
Photo of NU Jewish Bistro - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Ruben wrapped in puff pastry!

t5ieoVd_rf5d-MwVe5yEIA.text: I got the Jewish Bahn Mi which had smoked meat, jalepeno slaw and chopped liver spread. Flavors went perfect together. I prefer the way the Vietnamese do it, but NU's version was still very delicious. I chose coleslaw as my side and was not disappointed - the waitress said they use combination of mayo and vinegar, but I think it was more vinegar-based (which is what I prefer). I also split a Jewish Penicillin Soup w/ Matzo Balls w/ my boyfriend, and it is perfect for Pittsburgh's cold winters...especially if you're under the weather.  Food came out quickly, service was above average. Cost is reasonable for the amount of food you get.

ah2g_lOx9c3RsOZJJJ-V8w.text: My significant other and I used to be regulars at Nu. We came every saturday morning. The restaurant recently closed for renovations for a month and we anxiously waited for it to reopen.  It reopened on a saturday am and we obviously went to go to our favorite breakfast spot. Unfortunately we were so disappointed. They renovated the menu and got rid of everything that made the restaurant unique. They added a buffet of things that I didn't want nor liked and made me pay for it. Got rid of the latkes which is a staple of the establishment. The price for breakfast is absolutely ridiculous now; 52 dollars for the two of us and i did not have more than two bites of my food because it was so disappointing. 5 dollars for a small glass of orange juice? when i was forced to purchase a buffet of things i did not eat? i am just sad. Sigh, i guess we will have to find a new spot.   old Nu 5 stars.. new Nu 2 stars and thats being generous. Employees there are lovely though. Very nice and attentive.

QCrpoH2Y33EtovktXJT6nQ.text: I went for the nosh table and the nosh table I loved.  Nosh naysayer I am not.  Nosh nosh nosh.  Here is the nosh down (noshes graded on a scale of 1 to 5):  Latke hushpuppies: 4.5 noshness (like latkes from a mix except ball-shaped, aka nostalgia and whimsy in one)  Coconut shrimp: 5+ noshness (whoa! on both accounts of "hey this is SO not kosher as in not even trying to look a little kosher" and oh-my-treifness, these are awesome.  They were tender and flavorful)  Jalapeno-corn-cheddar balls: 2 noshness (only thing I didn't love)  Mini bagels: 5+ noshness (best bagel I've had in years, so soft and wonderful)  CHOPPED LIVER: 5+ noshness (brought to the table by the waitress, this was classic and perfect)  Israeli salad: 4 noshness (a little more complex than usual Israeli salads)  Fruit salad: unknown as I never got to it, but in theory I'm glad it was there  Greens with smoked meat: 4.5 noshness (yum yum yum and even better stirred into the Shakshuka)  Mac & cheese: 5 noshness (an excellent creamy version with big fat elbows)  Challah bread pudding: 5 noshness (sliced of tender goodness)  Spicy strawberry sauce: 5 noshness (I ate this with the shrimp)  Southwest Chipotle sauce: 5 noshness (I dipped the latke pups in this)  Peach-mango kutchen: 5 noshness (this is served like a slice of pie but tasted more like shortbread topped with chunky jam)  There was also applesauce & sour cream for the latkes, cream cheese & butter for the bagels, bagel chips, stuffed olives, and brownie bites and blueberry cake.  I chose Shakshuka and it was very good, with a more complex sauce than I've achieved on my own at home.  I didn't think I was being insanely glutonosh at the nosh table, but I was nearly stuffed by the time my entree arrived.  I tried, but I couldn't get too far into it.  Which is OK because we get to eat it for breakfast tomorrow.

oD_vLpAvGoT2iaGVSBnf-A.text: You're probably looking at this Yelp review because Pamela's is full and you're wondering if Nu is any good. My friend, you're doing the right thing. The only thing to worry about at this restaurant is if you have enough room for all the delicious food. You'll want to try it all.

5AwjVYm3hyZdjYkQH1IdCg.text: This Jeweeey little gem is planted nicely next to Pamela's, centrally located on Murray Ave in the heart of Squirrel Hill. With  all the Jewish Deli's extinct except for one, this establishment reminds of the culinary greatness of generations past. The comfort food will warm your belly and soul... well that and the amazing meats and latkes!!!  Limited hours so check before you venture out... they have a little buffet for noshing on assorted appetizers and desserts. It's even better than grandma used to make... trust me on this. Get ready to loosen your belt a notch or two

0GB5bwdftUUgZ8E4tjMqZA.text: Was originally going to go to Pamela's but they only accept cash and we're all about credit cards so we ended up at Nu, and boy was I sure glad we did!! It was also a lot less crowded than Pamela's.   If you order an entree you also get to enjoy the nosh table (a mini buffet). The nosh table comprises of sweet and savory breakfast & Jewish items. All I can say is: BAGELS! They are warm and chewy and oh so delicious. The challah bread pudding, chicken schnitzel, and latkes were also very yummy. For my entree, I got the LEO which was smoked salmon and eggs scramble which was also delicious and went great with the bagels! Service was great and quick, will definitely be back!
