Photo of NU Jewish Bistro - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. LEO
Photo of NU Jewish Bistro - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Nosh table

fZoUCEGdm8fL8zq21_rkbw.text: Perfect ambiance, amazing food and outstanding service. What an awesome place!  After checking out the nosh table I wasn't really prepared for the entree anymore but it (Shakshuka) was so good I simply couldn't not finish. And the chopped liver they keep bringing is just so so good.  Highly recommended to anyone looking for brunch in the area - and it is conveniently placed right next to a movie theatre, too.

VX-_rbLg34QrZ9ebrVyxbA.text: This is by far our favorite family brunch spot. If you are in line for Pamela's, skip the wait and go next door to the Nu bistro, which rarely has a wait. This is a great place if you have kids, just sit down and help yourself to the fabulous nosh, which is stocked with homemade mini bagels, Mac n cheese, soup, and fried coconut shrimp just to name a few. The brunch entrees are all delicious and will not disappoint.

psQJoAPGRL0nGwsXvR7XRw.text: I visited Nu yesterday with some friends for brunch.  Given that she'd been here several times before and had enjoyed it, my friend suggested it.  For my part, I was game because I'd never been before and had been wanting to try it, so I eagerly agreed.  My friend who'd been here before started off by ordering the poutine ($8) for the rest of us to share.   Having tried versions of poutine at several other restaurants in PGH, I'd say that Nu's version is my favorite.  Their version is composed of a bed of crispy battered shoestring fries, brown gravy, and cheese curds topped with fried onions.  It was served hot, such that the cheese curds partially melted and became stringy (in the best way!) as we ate the poutine.  Unlike many other versions I've tried, the flavor wasn't too salty, and the variance in temperature and texture made it fun and interesting to consume.  For my entree, I was torn between the grown up grilled cheese and the eggs benedict, but I settled on the "benny" with lox ($12) per the recommendation of my waitress.  Other than the lox subbing for the usual Canadian bacon, the benny pretty much took the classic form of poached eggs topped with Hollandaise sauce over open-faced English muffins.  It'd been awhile since I had this dish, and it hit the spot.  My only criticisms were that the lox made the overall effect a bit saltier than I'd like, and that I can make richer-tasting Hollandaise. :-)  My other friends ordered the leo ($12) and the corned beef sandwich ($10 x 2).  I didn't try any of their entrees, but one of the ones who ordered the sandwich said that it was the best corned beef he'd had in PGH.  All of them seemed quite satisfied with their orders.  Overall, I enjoyed my brunch at Nu.  Service was responsive to our needs (replacing napkins/silverware, bringing sour cream for latkes), and the atmosphere was casual, clean, and uncrowded.  I felt that prices were a bit high for the caliber of food, atmosphere, etc., but they weren't completely unreasonable.  As another reviewer mentioned, Nu represents a nice change of pace--and upgrade--from Pamela's for a weekend brunch experience.  I'll have to return to try the desserts, since the chocolate babka and egg cream sound scrumptious!

photos.caption: Photo of NU Jewish Bistro - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Poutine
Photo of NU Jewish Bistro - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Corned beef sandwich
Photo of NU Jewish Bistro - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Mix and match w/ corned beef sandwich

GnmECt_cxmoWSKafR9QeKw.text: My husband and I stopped in for breakfast on a Saturday. The entree selection, written on the chalk board was small but super varied. It featured basics (meat and 2 eggs) to complex (French dip style sandwich or a neat tomato stew). Each entree was $16 and included the nosh bar. Nosh bar had biscuits, Mac and cheese, latke hush puppies, fruit and a bunch of other stuff. The entrees don't include toast, hashbrowns, etc so this fills that out.   It's right next to Pamela's (they share a main entry) so you might have to fight through those waiting to be seated at Pamela's but you should be able to sit down right away. Nu does have a small amount of outside seating.   Only 4 stars since it is a little expensive but you don't walk away hungry.

UMW_DXzYcNK0ZlnlioGZhA.text: This establishment deserves 4 stars, but what separates 3 and 4 here is service. The service here is poor. There are a couple reasons for it, including both their workflow and at least one of the servers.   I won't go into any more detail on that, and will upgrade to 4 stars when service improves. Since we come here regularly, the opportunity is there.   It's unfortunate because the food is excellent here. I do mean excellent, and I also mean consistent. That's what makes this place a 4 for food.   We've had most items off their brunch menu, including a number of items off the full menu. The brunch menu is very excellent and the Israeli Shakshouka is our favorite. The tomato sauce is delicious, well spiced and well seasoned (salt). The toast is fantastic and the mamaliga (a form of polenta?), is also delicious.   A few other menu items that are solid are the tomato pesto omelet and the lox omelet.   In addition their bacon is excellent (thick cut, not thin lame wisps like next door).  So, if you don't care about the service and don't want to wait in line next door, eat here! The food is awesome!

photos.caption: Photo of NU Jewish Bistro - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Israeli Shakshouka

vfPZjCCmm0aTw3xFRhMFTA.text: My partner and I went here for brunch one Sunday and had a great time! The service is warm and friendly, the bistro feels homey. You order an entree and eat whatever you want off the "nosh" table, which has sides and desserts. The coffee was good too.

MutHiuSKPBIT6cEq61dOzg.text: This place gets 3-3.5 stars.  I have had good food here, and I'd probably come back. When I visited with a friend, we shared a chocolate egg cream ($2.50), which my Jewish grandmother is always talking about. I'd never experienced one of these before, and it's pretty weird. Like a chocolate milk soda...not bad but this has got to be an acquired taste.  We got the latkes ($4.99), which were very good, but in True Jew form I have to say they're not as good as my family's. They are crispy potato pancakes, served with applesauce if you ask, and sour cream otherwise. We shared a platter of their hand carved roast turkey ($9.99), which was very moist and tasty.  Honestly, there wasn't anything here that was life changing, but at the same time, it DID bring back happy memories of childhood Jewish holiday dinners. If you're here in Pittsburgh away from your family, and you miss your Bubbe's cooking, this would be a good place to go for a heaping helping of nostalgia. It's not the best restaurant in the 'Burgh, but if you desire True-blue-Jew-food...this is your place!  I'd probably be back to try their brunch, as I can't resist a lox & latke eggs benedict!

3Z6i_JhcESl8cRntJXkvVA.text: I love finding really good restaurants and this is one of them. The food is delicious and the staff is great. You order off the menu on the wall, and along with your order you're granted access to the nosh table, which could be a meal in and of itself.   My husband ordered the Reuben and said it was one of the best he's ever eaten. The corned beef practically melts in your mouth. I had the up street dip and it was amazing! I was full from the nosh table so my husband ate the other half of my sandwhich and decided that THAT was the best sandwich he's ever eaten.   If you want really good, non generic meal come here.

WbEr_tAbrUlNrBDxmY0jyg.text: I loved this place.  I've been here about a hundred times in the last couple years.  When they recently closed for renovations, it had been well over a year since the last time I woke up at home on a Saturday and didn't go to Nu.  But when they reopened, everything had changed.  My previous review, a well-deserved 5-star celebration of one of the best menus in the city, is now but an elegiac memory that will likely haunt me for the rest of my days in Pittsburgh.  I praised the babkas, now reformulated into bread pudding or kugel like cubes that don't hold a candle to what used to be one of the best desserts I've ever had in Western Pennsylvania.  I declared the latkes an unarguably superior breakfast potato, but they too are gone, replaced by an OK potato kugel.  The Jewbano, that creative and delicious fusion sandwich I recommended to every first-timer?  Gone, along with the ability to get the smoked meat it contained.  I scanned the new chalkboard menu (which honestly isn't easy to read from some of the seats, and there's no printed alternative), looking for my favorites, only to determine one by one that they had all vanished.  The turkey?  Gone.  The matzo balls?  Gone.  The kreplach, the grown-up grilled cheese, the fantastic omelette that had become an early Saturday go-to...all gone.  By my count, the 11 strongest items on the menu had either vanished or been replaced by a far inferior substitute.  It's possible not every item is gone forever.  I was told they'd change the menu regularly and update the website and/or their Facebook page with the menu each week...though sadly, that turned out not to be True.  The website still has the old menu (dated 6 months ago), and 2 weeks after the big reopening, the Facebook page has no relevant information on what might be served on any given day.  Right now, Nu is...OK.  It's not bad.  Pretty good.  Decent.  If I had walked in for the first time this month, I'd be reasonably pleased.  But given what it was, I'm sadder to write this 3-star review than I ever have been for a 1 or a 2.

7C4twOXcOkHWL_yJJmc0uA.text: Best brunch ever!! 15.99 for your amazing and large entree, AND nosh assortment table.  Usually no wait.  The Nu Benny was fantastic.  Great coffee.  Soooo much good food, come hungry!

photos.caption: Photo of NU Jewish Bistro - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Nu Benny
Photo of NU Jewish Bistro - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Nosh table free w entree

F_du9iqOC995UypOxukTFw.text: Very good food plus it is BYOB! Located right next to Pamela's in Squirrel Hill, NU is a gem in its own regard. I had matzah ball soup that hit the spot. Generally, the food is authentic and a great place for groups to go and enjoy a meal. Parking can be a bit tricky during peak times, but a reservation is monkeying not needed.

Kqk24xpPv6FCr2wGsIFYGg.text: Very pleasantly surprised. I guess maybe I just didn't know what to expect either, as Jewish food is pretty foreign to me.  We sat outside in the little patio area, which is nice to watch the foot traffic go by. Started off with the latkes, which were crispy perfection, served with sour cream.  My main dish was similar to a falafel or gyro. It was wrapped in pita bread with fried eggplant and tomato and it was awesome! Again, crispy eggplant is the best, don't give me mush! The side of coleslaw was done just right. Not too much mayo, but sweetened appropriately. I'm a hard judge towards coleslaw and it passed!  The presentation was adorable too! It came on a tray with the coleslaw in a Chinese take-out carton. Service was very friendly and our bill for two people was $30. Not bad in my opinion.  I will note that the menu only offered about four main dishes and the rest are sandwiches. But a limited menu isn't always a bad thing, as I found out!

x-Z5CMTOIw0FmjEzCxxUxA.text: I enjoyed my first experience here... I went on a Friday at lunch and was seated immediately. The server was kind and patient while I waited for my party. The atmosphere is quiet and palatable; I prefer quiet because I don't like yelling over music or other loud people.  I was able to find a parking spot on the first pass, pay parking (and they will ticket you).   I got a Reuben with macaroni salad and matzoh. The Reuben was interesting, more cured than I'd ever had before and thusly more flavorful; a welcome change of pace, but don't expect a "classic" taste. The macaroni salad was blah, and the matzoh was just right, mixed with a chicken broth and breast.   My friend got the "grown up grilled cheese" which was a nice twist with pesto.

photos.caption: Photo of NU Jewish Bistro - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Reuben, matzoh, macaroni

4nx9rPlG8bGAlMSI-dIUGQ.text: I'm not at all familiar with "new Jewish cuisine", so I don't have much to compare NU to, but I enjoyed my experience.   My friend and I sat outside and the server was very attentive. I ordered the Upstreet Dip, which seemed to be pretty popular. It was heavy, but not too greasy. The coleslaw was pretty standard. The presentation was nice- the sides are in takeout containers and the water is poured into Mason jars.   I've heard that their brunch is good- I'll have to go back to check that out!

photos.caption: Photo of NU Jewish Bistro - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Upstreet Dip and Coleslaw

aDTkVYBx1Ons8MaUIU67xQ.text: Banh mi with smoked corn beef: Sumptuous corn beef counterweighted by refreshing slaw and chopped liver. Surprising summer and afternoon-friendly.   Chocolate babka: Sumptuously sweet, ice cream just right, salt tickles

photos.caption: Photo of NU Jewish Bistro - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Banh mi with smoked corn beef; crunchy crackly fries

xqaNldP-6ClaIIa9e63XVw.text: What can you say about a place that presents as so warm and homey that you'd be comfortable just moving in!  Note though,  you have to walk through the front door to Pamela's and take a right but it makes all the sense in the world once you're in the deli. This place is unreal!  The Nosh bar simply kicks royal a**! The entree selections are not just tasteful but artistic in presentation and variety ! I opted for the good old "rueben" after eating them in NYC many times, the NU just made its own statement with the perfectly seasoned brisket and the presentation was plain old fashioned HEARTY! My lady ordered the Upstreet Dip and wow wee what a sandwich and side of the best horseradish ever. The chopped liver is the best I have ever eaten. Aside from NYC, this is probably the best Jewish deli I have had the pleasure, no...the honor of being a patron at. Love you folks. Keep it real as you're doing and for anyone reading this, run there...right now...even if its closed, that way you'll be first in when they open. :)

7Xg1HFsZkiehSELz2_a2zg.text: NU has quickly become a go-to brunch spot for us because of how incredible the food and service are. I'm almost embarrassed of how often we have brunch at NU during the weekend.   My favorite dish is the LEO- lox, eggs, and caramelized onions with caper cream cheese. It's simple but divine. The NU Benny is a delightful twist on Eggs Benedict with your choice of breakfast meat and light flavorful Hollandaise. The Reuben is a hit with my partner.   The nosh bar is a delightful spread of house-made mini bagels, macaroni and cheese, greens, challah bread pudding, Israeli salad, blueberry kuchen and more. They'll also bring out liver spread for you if you're inclined.   The wait staff are great and make you feel right at home. They're speedy but don't make you feel rushed.   We've taken a preschooler, a picky eater, and a brunch snob here. Everyone was happy. There's a kids menu and you can't go wrong with the Goy--slab bacon and eggs to order.   Check out NU if you're looking to elevate your brunch. Life pro tip: it's BYOB. Bring some bubbly and make a next-level mimosa with their fresh OJ.

7BjLsPwXHei-F-DBgtfZWw.text: Rude and inconsiderate staff. We had been coming to Pamela's next door for more than a decade and whenever it rains it is normal for people waiting in the long lines to tuck themselves under the awning of Nu's patio.   For some reason the employees on Fathers Day approached my father with an attitude. Called him bizarre and was very rude all because he wanted to stand away from the rain and be dry.  When I asked if he could just stand where he could be dry, they said, "no, he obstructs the view of our customers." Meanwhile, they had no customers and nobody was on their patio.   I had eaten here before when a friend invited me and thought it was average but a nice place. But I'm never going again after how they treated my father on Father's Day.

Mhn-8u2f7hSPGxQBKpocsw.text: Things have changed since my last visit here. NU Jewish bistro is now only open on weekends for brunch only. Weekday hours have been eliminated. While it is still a non Kosher establishment the brunch menu is still written on the chalkboard or they will bring you a paper copy. You can still sit where ever there is space. The sign says "seat yourself."  The price is pretty much fixed at $15.99 per entree. A new feature they added up front is something called a "nosh table." There are some rules regarding it. First, you can't have anything off the nosh table unless you order and entree. Second, you have no choice but to order an entree unless you are coming in to have a beverage. Most of the entrees come with eggs. They do however, have their own version of corned beef and brisket if you don't want eggs.  My husband decided to order the Reuben sandwich. I went with something they call "Nu Benny" which is lox covered by a type of egg Benedict served open faced on an English muffin. I was told I could substitute brisket or bacon for the eggs but I decided to stick with the original order.  As we were waiting for the entree we made our way up to the "nosh" table. Among the items are coconut covered shrimps, potato pancake hush puppies, mac and cheese, small homemade bagels, Israeli salad, canned fruit, challah sweetened with honey and dessert minis such as chocolate chip cakes, blueberry cakes, and peanut butter cookies. I sampled some of these and for the most part these nosh items were very good. Everything comes with appropriate sauces to accompany them and you get a separate plate there to bring your choices to the table.  When we got our entrees I found my English muffin extremely difficult to cut with a knife. I asked for a sharp knife and after receiving it asked why was that muffin so difficult to cut. My waitress had no answer but just gave me the knife.  The open face was good and the lox on the salty side which is what I would expect but to have to "work" my way at cutting the sandwich seemed tedious to me. My husband enjoyed his Reuben and thought it was flavorful.  Nu Jewish bistro continues to share the same space as Pamela's diner in Squirrel Hill but you must head right after entering Pamela's. Restrooms are only in Pamela's which you are permitted to use as a guest of this place.  I truly miss the old concept they had when I was first here a couple of years ago. I would wish they would sell the nosh bar by itself because I found some of my better eating finds there. However, it is what it is. The nice thing about visiting on a Sunday is that city metered parking is free so that's a plus.  Located on Murray Ave near Forbes which is in the heart of the Squirrel Hill business district metered parking is available or you can use public transportation.

photos.caption: Photo of NU Jewish Bistro - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Reuben with tiny salad
Photo of NU Jewish Bistro - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Nu Benny with eggs Benedict, lox, holandaise sauce and small salad
Photo of NU Jewish Bistro - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Coconut shrimp, potato pancake rounds, and homemade bagels in foreground

d7wCUxXTBoeySZfEMhDoBw.text: WOW! I'm a little sad that this place doesn't get nearly as much business as Pamela's which is right next door. Luckily, they are the same owners. From my understanding, the person that makes the food at NU is Pamela's sister.   The food is great! The menu is written on a huge chalkboard and is filled with both vegetarian options and also meat options. Although this place is a Jewish restaurant, there are options for non-kosher diners such as bacon! The entree was honestly my least favorite part of the meal. I got the veggie hash and it was tasty. The food was fresh, crispy and full of flavors and textures. I think I was just too excited about the nosh and nibbles table. The table was packed with little bagel bites (both regular and everything), bagel chips, fresh chopped fruit, coconut shrimp, kugels   The staff here is so welcoming and accommodating. My water was replenished without me having to ask. The staff also seemed to genuinely care if my meal was good we also had a conversation about other restaurants. I felt extremely welcomed here and I honestly can't wait to go back.

photos.caption: Photo of NU Jewish Bistro - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Veggie hash

JcatgVWt8ICpPtUvdABHlg.text: I have passed NU plenty of times but never tried it. I am so glad my friend and I decided to give it a try today!  We went for the weekend brunch. I love their brunch model: you pay about 16 dollars and you get an entree and access to the "nosh and nibble table"-what a cute name-, which is essentially a sides buffet.   While our waitress was getting our was getting our drink orders another staff person came over to talk to us. She was super friendly and informative. She told us that NU is actually owned by Pamela's and that Pamela's sister is actually the cook; how cool! Also NU makes almost everything in house and from scratch. She also gave us some suggestions for ordering and informed us that you could substitute bacon or brisket for the Eggs Benedict.  I decided to take her suggestion and I ordered the NU Benny with bacon instead of lox. It was delicious! The sauce was perfect and the English muffin it was served on was crisp and did not get soggy.  The side bar was amazing! Prefect snacking sizes. You must try the latke hush puppies and the mini bagels.  I was throughly impressed with NU. The staff was wonderful and the would was high quality and scrumptious. I can't wait to go back and try their other dishes.

photos.caption: Photo of NU Jewish Bistro - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. NU Benny with bacon
Photo of NU Jewish Bistro - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Desserts from the nosh table

Wnp15iUkGKk6-a7vUWOEcQ.text: This restaurant has to be one of Pittsburgh's best kept Brunch secrets - located right next door to one of Pittsburgh's most prominent Brunch locals - for which is there is constantly a wait. You get to just walk right in to Nu and have the best, most unique brunch experience.  There is  basic buffet fare that works for picky kids but also really interesting entree choices.  My favorite is the veggie hashbrowns with eggs. The coconut shrimp is excellent as are the hushpuppies.   There is definitely satisfaction walking right through the "others" waiting for a table and sitting down to a fantastic brunch with fresh coffee and great service.

7VhEa5elkI8HbA6n-rBvoQ.text: Stopped in for brunch one day while going through Squirrel Hill. For their weekend brunch, they offer a selection of menu items and an accompanying "Nosh Table" buffet style. Between the two of us, we went for the steak and eggs and smoked salmon entree selections. The steak and eggs were a delicious combo and I appreciated the accompanying salad. The eggs were over easy the way I ordered, so I appreciated that! The smoked salmon dish had great flavor as well.   The mosh table offered managers tasty looking sides: Mac & cheese, olives, stewed greens, soup, and more. Even though everything on one plate didn't *quite* look like a great mix, it was very tasty. On the sweet side, they had brownie bites, warm bread pudding, and small fruit tarts.   All of this + coffee to wash it down made for a really nice brunch!

photos.caption: Photo of NU Jewish Bistro - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

iFdJuQHHAOorKY-8A68vzw.text: I went here with a vegetarian friend (I am not vegetarian) and we were both super happy with our meals! The nosh table is honestly a great idea. I'm a mom now and I wish EVERY restaurant allowed you to grab some food to graze on before the main meal got there. Quite a gem right next to Pamela's!

LIBxVKT_bsSAgVnx9DOhYw.text: I want to eat brunch here every. single. day. until I die.   No joke: best brunch I have ever had!  I got the Eggs Benny with lox which was absolutely delicious and perfectly made. I hit up the nosh bar, which are little items you get free with any entree purchase and as much as you want (it is self serve/buffet style). I got hush puppies, mac and cheese, a blueberry walnut square and mango peach pie. Everything was sooooooo good!  This is going to be my go-to place for brunch whenever I am in Pittsburgh now! Can't wait to go back!

photos.caption: Photo of NU Jewish Bistro - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. love this sign in here - the place is filled with cheeky signs
Photo of NU Jewish Bistro - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. full menu
Photo of NU Jewish Bistro - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. fresh squeezed oj- sooo good and has a bit of shaved ice on top nice and cold

DW71IInb7pMnDo561XM0RQ.text: This place was definitely NOT worth it. This is the classic example of a restaurant doing hipster instagrammable food at a ridiculous upcharge. $16 gets you a small entree and access to a "Nosh Table." Our entrees were small and very poorly constructed, though very photogenic, sandwiches with a wad of meat in the middle of the bread and none by the crusts. They came with a side of literally 3 leaves of salad mix and a halved grape tomato. The sandwiches tasted fine but I've had significantly better sandwiches for half the price. The Nosh Table is an interesting concept, but it was definitely not worth the upcharge for the quality and taste.   Overall, pass on this place. You can get better food at much better prices elsewhere.

duvcT5yTLinGGte50yCaqw.text: Highly recommend this brunch spot! Great food, fast service, and friendly staff. The LEO (scrambled eggs and lox) was exactly what I needed on a Sunday afternoon. My boyfriend got the brisket and eggs, which was delicious too. There are many yummy offerings at the nosh table (all you can eat, included with the purchase of an entire). The house made bagels are superb -  very soft and plush.

bLY5zbWCN-xKYCjsbu9-IQ.text: Looking for a new spot to brunch? Put NU Jewish Bistro in Squirrel Hill on your list and here's why:  1. With the purchase of a brunch entree, you gain access to a NOSH bar that includes varying bites such as latke puppies, challah bread pudding, corned beef and cabbage soup and lots of other nibbles. 2. Lox, brisket, 15-day corned beef and bagels are all made in house. 3. The joint is BYOB with no corkage fee, so hit the Murray Ave. wine and spirits beforehand. 4. It's only open on the weekends from 10-4!

photos.caption: Photo of NU Jewish Bistro - Pittsburgh, PA, United States
Photo of NU Jewish Bistro - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

sICii2NMDXuK5li9VtK-RA.text: I really don't get why NU Jewish Bistro has plenty of seats during brunch time while there is a one hour wait at next door Pamela's. Maybe it's because it's not clear how to get into this little cafe (you have to walk through the front door to Pamela's and take a right), but it's so weird to me. I really like this place since brunch here is pretty good and you don't wait!   My favorite part is the nosh board up by the window. For brunch, you can start off right away with some yummy bites, like latke hush puppies, coconut shrimp, challah bread pudding, and chopped liver. It's all part of brunch and you just pick an entree - like brisket and eggs, or lox scrambled eggs. I've also been here for lunch and the sandwiches are great. The service is pretty quick and friendly to boot.

photos.caption: Photo of NU Jewish Bistro - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Brunch - L.E.O: house cured lox, carmelized onions, scrambled eggs

GjGKIHebVOfnUoKF8U9uHg.text: I had the veggie hash and it was delicious! Good coffee and made from scratch items. Also the staff was extremely polite and helpful. Would recommend.

-Mpl4ScliCiLZSAoH4UASw.text: One of the hidden gems of Pittsburgh! It only has weekend hours and it shares an entryway with Pamela's diner so it's often overlooked but it's a great place to grab brunch without having to bother with lines. The place is never more than half full when we go so the waiters are responsive and the place is easy to talk in.  Food: EVERYTHING is good at NU Jewish bistro. You get access to their nosh table when you order an entree which is literally a buffet of homemade baked goods and finger foods. What is amazing is the detail spent on each of the dishes. You see mini bagels and think 'whatevs' but they are some of the best plain bagels I've had and pair well with their homemade jams. The coconut shrimp, latkes hush puppies, mac n cheese, corn muffins and kuchen cake are all very well-executed and let you pick between sweet and savory options depending on your mood. I highly recommend trying stuff you normally wouldn't try because even the simple stuff is amazing. As for entrees, I consistently find myself getting the Reuben with extra kraut because it's just superb. The non-marbled rye is not overpowering and always toasted and buttered to perfection. The corned beef is very flavorful and comes out warm, tender, and slightly caramelized. Unlike smallman deli, their russian dressing isn't sweet and is just creamy and tangy which I prefer. We've had the brisket and eggs which is a little simpler, just slab of tender and savory brisket and eggs as described. The same delicious brisket is featured in their dip sandwich however I found the horseradish cream sauce too heavy and overpowering to have regularly. The shakshuka and benny options are nice well-rounded dishes but definitely on the lighter side.  Overall NU Jewish bistro is a great place to try if you've never been or if you want a chef-quality brunch without the brunch crowd. Highly recommended!

V9Hesq93KjKkKUJ8EjUAXQ.text: People need to eat here! I ate brunch on a Saturday morning, and there miraculously was space (which is important especially since Pamela's is next door and always SO crowded)! I snapchatted my food and at least 5 people asked where I was... so it's not too well known in my circle at least, but definitely should be!!   FOOD If you get an entree, all of which are $15.99, it comes with unlimited access to the nosh table aka the brunch buffet table of delicious Jewish snacking foods, brunch items, sauces, desserts. I had the shakshuka, which was perfectly seasoned and chunky with basted eggs and mamaliga corn bread. My friend had eggs benedict and portions were so big (alongside the nosh table) we both had enough left over to bag and takeout after!   SERVICE Amazing. As an example: when I ordered, the waitress asked if I'd be okay with the spice level of my shakshuka and brought out a tiny ramekin with the shakshuka so I could sample it!! She refilled water regularly and talked to us about our day. I'm won over omg.   Just go eat here if you haven't already.

photos.caption: Photo of NU Jewish Bistro - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. LEO
Photo of NU Jewish Bistro - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Nosh table is the best
Photo of NU Jewish Bistro - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Shakshuka below, Nu benny above. And our first plate of nosh table yummies!

ywapaOEtAqvxaAftEjJ26Q.text: Oh it's definitely a hidden gem! I don't understand why it's not as packed as it should be. My friends and I came here for brunch. The way it works is that you order an entree for ~$16 and have unlimited access to the appetizer table. You can actually just fill up your belly from the appetizer table and then take your entree to go (hint hint).   I ordered the brisket and eggs plate for the entree. The brisket was a tad dry, but the unlimited appetizers made up for it. So lets talk about this appetizer buffet. There's savory finger food, like coconut shrimp. Omgsh the "chopped liver" (looks like pate) with some toasted baguette was absolutely phenomenal. I can probably eat that stuff all day, every day. There's also an abundance of desserts to choose from too. Remember, this is ALL YOU CAN EAT appetizers (and desserts) buffet with the purchase of an entree.   Now I know, Jewish food is so unique and delicious! I highly recommend this place for brunch if you have a big appetite and want to try something different. I'm drooling just thinking about that chopped liver pate on top of a crispy slice of toasted baguette. Yummmmm.

photos.caption: Photo of NU Jewish Bistro - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Brisket and eggs

g8KUv5IBulpwc5f7Zjgcdw.text: We decided to check out NU Jewish Bistro on a whim in Squirrel Hill. For the money spent, it is by far one of the best experiences in Pittsburgh. The menu is always the same but the Nosh table changes periodically.  I had the Brisket and Eggs. The brisket was nice and tender. Not dry at all. Very tasty. My eggs were cooked over medium perfectly. When that yolk broke, it ran everywhere. Just the way I like!   She had the NU Benedict, and while I don't care for hollandaise, it was absolutely beautiful. The eggs were cooked perfectly. The corned beef which was include was by far some of the best corned beef I'd ever tasted. Salty and shaved paper thin!   I can't even begin to describe the Nosh Table, however a meal could be made of it in and of itself if you choose to take your entree home. It was excellent.  I regret not taking a photo of the table for Yelp! But I will the next time we go and go we shall.

photos.caption: Photo of NU Jewish Bistro - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Brisket &amp; Eggs over Medium.
Photo of NU Jewish Bistro - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. NuBenny with Corned Beef

VtT07rNhE4bKVz9QgNUsTw.text: Hands down the best brunch I ate in a long long time. The veggie hash is simply sublime. I cannot day enough good things about the place, I just wish it was open during the week too. We were there today and the place wasn't full which I simply don't understand why. The concept is that you order a main dish (huge!) and then you can get the sides you want from the buffet table. The bagels are so good, ressembling Montreal style bagels (the only True good ones ;) ). The service was also excellent. This will be our regular brunch spot. Just go and enjoy the veggie hash!

4LTA1v2l7JG-fhujFw6uAA.text: The people of this city are seriously sleeping on this place, and it's criminal. This is my absolute favorite brunch spot. There is something here for everyone from meat lover to vegetarians. They are BYOB with NO CORKING FEE which is so hard to come by in Pittsburgh. And don't forget the gnash table that has delicious latke puppies and house made desserts! Service is always so quick, even when it's a bit more crowded we're always in and out in no more than 30 minutes. So the next time you have to wait an hour for a table at Pamela's, just hop in right next door and have the best meal Squirrel Hill can offer you.

iXph-4CX95TfNA_HYwlaxA.text: I really liked this place for lunch.  Went with another couple and we mixed up the order so we could all taste different things.  The Jewbano was really good and all the meats were cured in house.  Great attention to detail with everything.  It isn't the absurd portions you find in NYC deli's but I don't think that is the angle they are going after.  Just good quality sandwiches in a nice location.

C3ah30KYaQ6jHanBgnIG-g.text: Had an amazing brunch this morning at NU. Let me begin by telling you I love brunch and have eaten at probably every brunch in Pittsburgh, the best many times. This by far was my favorite and let me tell you why.  In addition to eight main courses, there is this homey little buffet with amazing things on it.  Before i get to the main courses, let me talk about the service (excellent) and the buffet of " noshes". Wow-  this amazing potato kugel, chopped liver to die for, bagels, many different spreads, fresh fruit salad, biscuits, bannana bread, pumpkin noodle kugel, this chocolate babka bread pudding and this buttery jam torte. I am sure i forgot a few things and the spread may change from week to week, but between the two of us, we tried most of it and it knocked our socks off. You help yourself to the table and then you choose one of eight entrees. I had shashuka, this spicy tomato stew with onions and a fried mush topped with two perfectly poached eggs. It was spicy, but not excessively so, and i could not have enjoyed it more. My friend had the house made lox scrambled with carmelized onions and eggs. This was topped with a ball of insanely great cream cheese, lemon and capers.  I was glad to see they kept the montreal smoked brisket and there were two choices, maybe three, that had that. There was a bacon and eggs choice and a vegetarian choice, and a few others. The best part was the entire meal was under $20 per person, and the portions were so big, i'm having shashuka for dinner again tonight. Cant wait to go back next weekend!

GcPP_sMUFkP4qHEv8UoBGA.text: Tthis place really stands out. We had the latkes, the chicken soup with matzoh ball, the brisket with challah bread sandwich, among others. All great. Nice service. If you're in town get out to Squirrel Hill!

eOVhgwSLc0J0Xf7LMdqSDA.text: they have chicken soup with matzo (matzah whateva) balls and other beauties :,) jewish penicillin. go here now.

3MPCrS7O1D6FG7lt2LnM5A.text: Absolutely wonderful. Service was excellent. I shared the Sabich and the Bahn Mi, both of which were perfectly delicious in their own way. The jalepenos on the Bahn MI gave it a kick but not overwhelmingly spicy. I can't wait to go back!!

H8vOGh-VBbGaLS0ETuj2SA.text: This is a very good place. Barley soup, pickles, and Mandelbrot were excellent. Sandwiches were also good. Definitely coming back.

IohtRfVQ4LlwKAtM6zcdkQ.text: This was my second visit to NU. I recommended it to several co-workers. We ordered take out corned beef sandwiches. To begin, we were the only people there, our order took twenty minutes to prepare 3 corned beef sandwiches. The corned beef sandwiches are on the pricey side, $10.00 a sandwich (no sides). The corned beef had so much fat on it, it was difficult to eat. I was embarrassed that I suggested this place, as my co-workers stated the sandwiches had too much fat. We were disappointed.

i2RJlqf8L_lS0Q57u_QGGQ.text: I went here last night with my wife for the first time.  I've had one facsimile of Montreal smoked meat before...at the Mile End Deli in Brooklyn, NY (twice) and it was close but no cigar.  I think Nu actually nails it..a delicious, nicely stacked smoked meat sandwich, not too moist, not too dry, taste is right on.  My wife ordered a brisket sandwich..a little less thrilled only because it tasted like her homemade brisket (and her mother's brisket before her).  I understand that Nu is not trying to be your traditional NY style Jewish deli but I think that staples like knishes and hand cut fries should be on the menu.  Their only presence was in a knish-based sandwich and poutine.  Luckily the server supplied a serving of shoestring fries, not a great substitute but OK.   BTW, the cole slaw is excellent and served in a chinese takeout container, cute.  I would come back and get the smoked meat in a heartbeat.  Pleasant surprise in Squirrel Hill.

mAA27zTTAxXvFDJsEpV7_g.text: I've been here twice and both times the food and service were great. As a vegetarian i didn't find a ton of options, but I really loved the Sabich sandwich, a soft pita filled with fried eggplant, beets, and other treats. I love how the food is served on a cafeteria tray over paper with little Chinese take-out boxes for the sides! Speaking of sides: delicious! Best pickle and coleslaw I've had in a while. Their challah makes phenomenal toast. Real deli food at its best!

s5UBoxO23GlEQ9UQ_YlY8g.text: Has the best, tenderest brisket sandwich I've had in many, many years. Right up there with the top New York City quality, and that's saying a lot. Everything else so far was very good, too. Also a nice comfortable space.

SaZOnhlFJ1Vbyut6kHwp-A.text: Seeing as it was a Peruvian restaurant just a few years ago, I didn't expect too much authenticity. The chef however tried really hard, and many of the meals were fairly close. The desserts were especially good. Probably brought me closer to a heart attack by about 5 years, however.

nIZWjNM8lUJ-Zsl-4CqDfg.text: I went to Nu tonight with my husband and it was excellent. We needed to eat quick to get to a movie, and the service could NOT have been better. The highlight was that we ordered the reuben and it was amazing. I will definitely be going back.

rLwzE_hoUIe3ir9eFMUS8Q.text: Decided to try Nu for lunch as we had seen it written up in the Chronicle, always nice to support local businesses.  Nu is located right next to Pamela's, apparently where their other restaurant had been.  It is a long narrow space, tables close to each other,  with the open kitchen in the back.  After seating ourselves, we got down to studying the menu.  It had the usual "Jewish-y" described items,but all with a updated description.    It is not particularly on the healthy side or much for vegetarians.  My friend and I decided to order several things and share.  We each got the chicken soup with a (hard) matzo ball.  It was OK, fortunately not over salted. We shared the chicken liver, which was  done as a pate in a glass jar and it was very good served with rye toast.  We got the brisket sandwich which I felt was underwhelming.  It is served open face on soft white bread that got quite mushy, not a lot of meat and some gravy.  It comes with a side of cole slaw in a "take out" container.  I did see a couple sandwiches come out and they were not overstuffed as you usually see in a deli.  The food is served on small metal paper lined trays which took up the whole tables.  I would prefer dishes.....just saying....since you asked....not sure if I will come back here .
